title: Thursday, 14th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Hang on, talk among yourself for a moment ......

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Soundbuy Morning
Deep Breath everyone... Morning all
Bryan Morning guys, in few hours Draghi is going to speak..... end of QE??
BE11:08am

I need to go fix something.

DRichi Good morning all
Shinshin @bryan - ..in Europe. BoJ still printing away.
Soundbuy BE - the DIY enthusiast....
Blank canvas Unilever? in the category of "nothing to do about Brexit"
jaws g morning.
Shinshin Oil back to $55 by Dec ?
Flaneur @BE - Whats the official ML line on the latest YouGov survey?https://twitter.com/YouGov/status/1007175984792195072
BE11:11am

Right! Back, sorry.

Manxish Morning each
FATDAZ Morning all
BornCynic Morning - PZ Cussons please BE - that is if you have anything in your inbox...........
11:12 am
BE11:12am

That brief hiatus was while I went to change what we were about to publish on Unilever.

Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 3,991, down 158.73 (-3.82%), High: 4,167, Low: 3,969, Volume: 3.03m
Peace and Love Morning BE morning right people
BE11:12am

Who are at a Deutsche Bank conference this morning.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

And have soft warned on Brazil sales, due to a truckers' strike.

BE11:13am

As well as saying (possibly confirming) that you can't get into the FTSE 100 if your HQ is in Holland.

kim Just a trucker's strike?
Bryan The CEO of Roche is in London and heard that Roche is going to invest 4B in oncology
BE11:14am

So, what happened was that RBC sent out something early doors saying the E150m hit Unilever was taking on sales was a quarter of Brazil quarterly revenue.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

But it isn't.

BE11:14am

So they've just sent an update saying:

BE11:14am

We understand from investors attending the Deutsche Bank conference where Unilever lowered its expectations for 1H sales growth that Brazil accounts for 6.5% of group sales. In our note earlier this morning we estimated 4%. Assuming 6.5%, the €150m lost sales attributed to the Brazilian truckers strike would equate to about 16% of Q2’s sales in Brazil, not the 25% we had estimated … which we think still seems a lot for an 11 day strike. [Incidentally, with the Brazilian real having depreciated by 20% relative to the euro compared to last year’s average, we wonder what the 6.5% assumes about exchange rates.]

Whether 16% or 25%, what is apparent is that other bits of the business have been unable to compensate for the sales lost in Brazil.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

We think that Unilever’s dual target on organic revenue growth and margin expansion deprives the company of the flexibility that is needed to succeed in the current challenging consumer environment. The risk is that Unilever will neglect marketing investment to hit the margin target, exacerbating top-line weakness and penalizing market share. Underperform.

Dec69 - Skeptic Good Morning, are PZ Cussons going to crack Nigeria? Seems a thorn in the side...
LK Hyman @Blank canvas RDS stayed in the FTSE100 when it rejigged its corporate structure ... but ULVR can't? Sounds incompetent
BE11:15am

......... so, we're probably not looking at deeper problems in Brazil, which was the gist of the first RBC commentary.

RA hello
Shinshin Seems odd that something as big as Unilever would see so much impact from a minor labour dispute running for a short time in just one terrirtory
BE11:16am

But we are looking at a pretty lacklustre performance across the wider group that E150m can't be offset somewhere.

tangledodyssey Polman way overpaid for very poor performance
Dec69 - Skeptic Higher margin territory @ShinShin
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Whether that's worth 3.5% off Unilever live is questionable. But then, the market really doesn't like seemingly significant guidance tossed out during conference appearances.

BE11:17am

There's a tendency to over-read the significance.

Pharma @BE, by "offset" do you mean "fudged"? Not something we should be encouraging.
FATDAZ @BE I wonder if the markets are sensitive to any neg news from EMs at the moment
BE11:18am

(@LK Hyman: why incompetent? Perhaps they just don't give a stuff. If I ran Unilever, I'm not sure I would lose much sleep over which index the stock was and wasn't in.)

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Here's Morgan Stanley for a second opinion.

tangledodyssey Polman, SJW CEO, way overpaid, feels sheltered in Holland
BE11:20am

Unilever has guided to 1H sales growth to be below its FY guidance range of 3%-5%, due to a short-term distribution disruption in Brazil (c.8% of group sales), caused by an 11 day transport strike. 2Q sales impact is expected to be ~€150m, with inventories and pipeline re-filling in 2H. This implies ~80-100bps LFL impact for 2Q18, i.e. less than 2.3% LFL for 2Q18 (MSe currently 3.2% for 2Q18 and 3.8% FY18). Theoretically flowing this through to FY18 would imply a 20-30bps hit to our FY18 LFL to ~3.5%, although we note Unilever expects to recover the sales. We believe there had been some awareness of the strike in the market already. We do not anticipate a material impact on consensus earnings estimates.

FATDAZ RE FTSE don't remember a leading Ad agency being kicked out when it briefly re domiciled its HQ out of the UK either
Pseudonym I wonder what the impact on FTSE-100 less ULVR will be when the ETF's all re-balance...
undefined
LK Hyman @BE Incompetent because they should know how important inclusion in the FTSE100 is to trackers which form a considerable part of the market, and they need to get 75% approval from shareholders to shift their HQ to Rotterdam. They should have followed the Shell playbook.
11:21 am
BE11:22am

(@LK Hyman: if that's the case, can't shareholders just vote against it? I'm still unsure why anyone should be bothered much.)

BE11:22am

Speaking of Dutch companies .....

Relx PLC (REL:LSE): Last: 1,592, down 63 (-3.81%), High: 1,645, Low: 1,586, Volume: 3.32m
estrangedcapitalist Gents, I'm alright. This is the first FT Live after the fire at Mandarin Oriental (right next to Royal Thames backgammon). Appreciate all who reached out
Pharma Must say that telling a significant minority of your shareholders that they can no longer own the shares seems rude at least.As Bryce says, they can vote against, and if they do it would represent an enormous waste of time. Seems like something the CEO at least should pay attention to.
11:23 am
BE11:23am

It's FT style to cap up companies and organisations you spell out, like IAG, and first-cap ones you can pronounce, like Opec.

RA nasdaq is a bubble
BE11:24am

So, how are we meant to pronounce Relx?

LK Hyman @BE It's more likely that shareholders will now vote against it. And presumably a lot of big FTSE100 will have to dump ULVR willy nilly
BE11:24am

Frankie Goes to Hollywood style? Or is it more of a click at the end, like Khoisan?

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Anyway.

Pseudonym Relsh pinyin style..
BE11:25am

UBS saying sell on valuation, but the interesting stuff is on the journals business.

LK Hyman @BE big FTSE trackers, sorry
BE11:26am

Journals account for c20% of group revenues and c23% of adjusted EBIT. In FY12-17 Elsevier has delivered c3% adj. EBIT growth. We now believe this growth is at risk as European institutions push for an author pays model while US institutions increasingly unbundle. Our downside scenario where 1) the subscription model in Europe (25% of STM revs) is replaced by an Open Access model with an average APC of £2300 vs. £3000 rev per article today; and, 2) US institutions (42%) only subscribe to top journals implies sizeable earnings and valuation risk. Our base case sees EBIT grow c2-3% while the downside case sees EBIT falling c1% pa in FY18-23 resulting in EBIT in FY23 being c12% below our base case. This would in turn reduce our implied STM EV/EBITDA multiple of 10.8x to 8.8x and reduces our RELX valuation by £1.05 per share.

tangledodyssey Maybe the boys from Brazil will come back and have another pop at Unilever? S/holders can see that ULVR has gone back to sleep. Holland is more difficult for takeovers, that may be the real reason for redomiciling?
nichoman journals seems v ripe for disruption - especially academic stuff
11:27 am
BE11:28am

Academic publishing is a subject we've touched on many, many times here in the past. It's even worse in terms of designed inefficiencies, closed shops and rampant anticompetitive practices than most publishing.

nichoman @LK Just relx. The Ftse and unilever will be ok.
Tom Dalgleish BE, as Robt Maxwell realised too
BE11:29am

And in that 70% of academic publishing revenues come from universities, which are generally speaking publicly funded, it's an area that probably deserved a bit of proper scrutiny.

BE11:29am

UNESCO data indicates c1% of US and European GDP is spent funding
academic research.

Tom Dalgleish Maxwell would get the content free and sell it back to universities because they had to have it
LK Hyman @tangledodyssey The boys from Brazil would have to come back for ULVR without Uncle Warren who doesn't do hostile. Cant' see it myself.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

And average revenue per published article of €1900!

BE11:30am

For Reed alone, average rev per article of c£3000!

Soundbuy Diversified Gas & Oil suspended on Proposed Acquisition..............https://www.investegate.co.uk/diversified-gas---38-oil--dgoc-/rns/proposed-acquisition/201806141100024112R/
Tom Dalgleish ......and no journalists salary
tangledodyssey @LKH: Perhaps, there is value there, Polman is looking after himself.
Pharma Had to laugh when I read here that Norwegian universities were going to stop subscribing to Elsevier journals. What the ***** are researchers supposed to do when the article they want to read is published in one?@BE €2,000 is a pretty good estimate of the cost *to the researcher* of publishing an open source article.
BE11:32am

And it's worth bearing in mind that journals don't even pay for peer review. The costs are a barrier to effective distribution among academics, who get very very little back.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

So open access makes a lot of sense, except to academics, who really really like their stuff appearing in Nature or whatever.

Pharma @BE, as someone who has peer-reviewed many academic articles, I do it because it helps lower the noise level.
BE11:33am

Anyway, back to the RELX sell case.

BE11:33am

We believe an earnings acceleration which drove material outperformance over the last 3yrs is coming to an end. While RBA growth looks to have the capacity to remain inflated (with US Auto Insurance running at c9% in Q118) we are concerned STM and Legal momentum is turning more negative: STM from growing structural risks; and, Legal from an unwinding of market share gains in FY16-17 with industry growth still lacklustre (US legal billable hours fell -0.5% in Q118). Our base case sees underlying EBIT slow from +6% in FY16-17 to +5% in FY18-21.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

(@Pharma: I salute your indefatigably.)

undefined
Pharma Otherwise science just becomes one more part of the internet...
A. M. @Pharma: they will go to arXiv, or contact the authors?
Shinshin There's a pirate site in the 'stans isn't there with a copy of pretty much every article ?
A. M. @Shinshin: I've heard tell of such a place.
patatbat @LK how is RDSA in the ftse100 when its hq is in the netherlands?
Tom Dalgleish indefatigability surely
Pharma @A.M. I'm not in a field where arXiv has any traction (life sciences), and the authors cannot redistribute the published article, only their manuscript (not copy-edited, and generally much harder to read). You used to pay £100 or so for reprints you could post out, but pdfs put a stop to that.Believe me, having a library with decent subscriptions is essential.
BE11:36am

(@Shinshin: a sci hub, you might call it? I couldn't possibly link to such a thing.)

11:36 am
BE11:37am

(@Tom: yes, I meant indefatigability. Google spellcheck doesn't like it though.)

BE11:37am

Back on topic. Soap.

PZ Cussons PLC (PZC:LSE): Last: 221.40, down 11.4 (-4.90%), High: 227.80, Low: 215.00, Volume: 971.83k
Soundbuy Smurfit up 3% earlier.........any notes doing the rounds or a reaction to Janus Henderson adding a tad?
11:37 am
BE11:38am

Nigeria keeps on getting worse.

A. M. @Pharma: that means that the journals actually do some copy-editing (unlike LaTeX-based journals, I suppose?)
LK Hyman @patatbat Because, although the HQ is in the Hague the parent company is registered in England and Wales. Something like that. ULVR are missing a trick
Soundbuy Folks not washing anymore?
Pharma @A.M. yes, especially the better ones. Open source tends to spend much less on this, and on page-layout too.
BE11:39am

UK has remained on the guidance given in March but Nigeria has worsened. And it's not entirely clear why.

Forester Part of me thinks that with equities at an high, risks all over the place then Unilever might be safe place to hide for a while, with or without truck disputes in Brazil!
BE11:40am

The oil price rally should've stabilised Nigeria a bit, for FX reasons as much as anything. But it seems the soap market -- or, at least, Cussons' bit of it -- is still contracting.

Pharma (note, Elsevier have good an bad journals in this respect, generally correlated with their reputation. There really are journals were the c**p science goes to die)
11:40 am
BE11:41am

So. Earnings "towards the bottom" of previous guidance of £80-85m,

A. M. @Pharma: wasn't there a minor scandal a couple of years ago about lots of dodgy papers/journals making their way into Elsevier?
BE11:42am

(@Pharma: I know a journal where the editor published a very bad paper because he'd had an affair with the author, who had videos.)

BE11:42am

(@Pharma: so, yeah, variable quality.)

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Here's Numis.

BE11:43am

Given the ongoing challenges in Nigeria, little improvement is expected in FY 2019e. Trading in Europe and Asia remains inline with expectations. Accordingly we have reduced PBT downgrades by 2% and 11% in FY 2018e and 2019e respectively. On our revised forecasts the shares are currently trading on 16.4x PE and 9.8x EV/EBITDA for CY 2018. Given the ongoing challenges in its core markets we maintain our Hold rating and lower our TP from 255p to 230p.

Pharma @A.M. it's not publisher specific. The retraction watch site can be entertaining (or depressing). Particularly look out for the heads of biology at the CNRS in France, who seem to have a tradition of publishing dodgy science.
Shrink Hindustan Unilever doing quite well though.
BE11:43am

And Cazenove.

patatbat @lk thanks.. any idea what happens to london shareholders of ULVR then if it is delisted. If they were to get the dutch line equivalents wont there be huge dilution?
11:43 am
BE11:44am

On the back of persistent challenging trading conditions in Africa, we
reduce our FY18e Adj PBT by 3.6% to £80.2m, and FY19e Adj PBT by
7.8% to £84.9m. We maintain our Neutral rating, with a reduced price
target of 250p (previously 260p).

undefined
A. M. @Pharma: I'm a bit shocked, I thought that INRIA/CNRS were places doing decent work (though I'm related to a different field)
Pharma @BE I'm guessing that sort of story is not limited to academic publishing.
DJ Revolution Bars?
LK Hyman @patatbat No dilution, the shares will be listed in London as well as the Netherlands, they just won't qualify for the FTSE100 it seems.
BE11:46am

(@Pharma: true, true. Though when it happens elsewhere, there's less risk of poor research poisoning the well of follow-up research.)

BornCynic Many thanks for that BE.
FATDAZ re ULVR and FTSE 100 how will the dividend income be replaced if ULVR exit from the index ? not easily is my thought
Pharma @A.M. don't worry, the CNRS did an investigation, and found it was all OK.
Tom Dalgleish Could World Cup be a time to bury bad news and find exotic villains?
patatbat @lk im confused? Where will it be listed then doesnt the 250 require London HQ as well. I was under the impression the London listing will just be removed
11:48 am
BE11:48am

What else, then? We're in Fed aftermath so everything's a bit quiet.

hornblower also RBG
Excel Developer @BE: Retail sales better this month
Excel Developer well they beat forecast that is
nichoman any uk implications for media merger mania in US?
LK Hyman @FATDAZ If all the trackers sell ULVR, which is about an average yielder (isn't it? 3.3% or thereabouts) there shouldn't be much effect because ULVR divis will be replaced by increased weighting in the other "99". Pure speculation on my part!
BE11:51am

The interest in Unilever has caught me a tad by surprise. Rule 5.1.6 in FTSE's playbook is the one you want to read.

LK Hyman @patbat ULVR say they'll keep the premium London listing. It won't go in the 250 though.

Which says FTSE will only assign a stock UK nationality if is fails a liquidity criteria in its country of incorporation.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Unilever's Netherlands listing is considerably more liquid than its UK line, so that doesn't apply.

BE11:53am

Want the flowback details? Here's SocGen from ages ago.

FATDAZ @LK it is an average yielder but the divi is dependable and that cant be said for all FTSE 100 names it will just concentrate the reliance on HSBC Shell BP etc
LK Hyman @BE I'd be mightily surprised if RDSA failed a liquidity criterion in the Netherlands ....
BE11:54am

Excel Developer Does anybody hold a DAX ETF? I just opened an IShares position and got stung 1% FX. Presumably I'll get stung another 1% upon exit.
11:54 am
BE11:54am

So. "gross maximum potential supply from ULVR LN deletion from indices as -160.3m shares/-67 days but we think only around half of this is likely and from FTSE100 and All-Share (-81m/-34 days), as the rest should be offset by increases in UNA NA. Overall net potential across all indices is the second set of rows for UNA NA, and we calculate this being supply of
-32.4m shares/-7.5 days."

Excel Developer because it is EUR demoninated
undefined

Oh, right. Yes. We should probably mention media mega M&A-ageddon in the States.

AT&T's buying Time Warner so Comcast is buying most of Fox but Fox is buying Sky but Comcast is also buying Sky but Disney is buying Fox and slso Sky. I think that's accurate.

BE11:59am

Comcast overnight offering ~$55B at $65B for Fox, or a 19% premium

Soundbuy Ent One +3% on media mania then...............

What does this mean for the Sky offer? Dunno. Here's Suntrust.

Soundbuy ITV flat.........
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

We believe it is clear that Comcast has the desire to become a global content company that can ultimately compete with the likes of Netflix (NFLX, Hold, Thornton) whose market capitalization now exceeds that of Comcast and whose once-questionable international execution strategy has clearly demonstrated it is possible to successfully market content across borders. We think CMCSA with these transactions could mark the formation of a global OTT platform with combined majority ownership of Hulu (Private) and Sky’s (SKY-LON, NR) OTT platform.

Pseudonym @Excel You'll get you r1% back when the pound crashes at the next brexit crisis.
BE12:00pm

We believe the full detailed disclosure and associated Q&A surrounding the proposed acquisition of the Fox assets along with the remainder of Sky that Fox does not own currently should begin to lift the overhang of fear on the stock. Obviously, the one caveat lies with the competitive response of Disney and the potential requirement for Comcast to increase its bid yet again.

FATDAZ @excel understood
Excel Developer #Dax #GBP: looks like a synthetic ETF is required, Xtrackers (XDAX) DAX UCITS ETF (DR) 1C
Blank canvas Thanks for everything today, especially Unilever
nichoman @excel try Xtrackers or vanguard if not ishares
Excel Developer @Fatdaz: and that one probably uses equity derivatives, same as CFDs.
Excel Developer @nichoman: yeah, got it, XDAX is ticker.
BE12:02pm

Note the report overnight from CNBC, I think, saying Disney has begun to explore raising additional financing to bump its offer with a better cash bit.

SoS @excel, I think sipp and isa providers should be more transparent re fx. charges. Sometimes very diff to find.
12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Here's Morgan Stanley on that likelihood.

BE12:03pm

Assuming an 80/20 debt/equity mix, to allow the Class B shares held by the Murdoch's to receive DIS shares but the majority of the remaining shareholders to receive cash, and a similar valuation as Comcast's
offer, we estimate Disney's pro forma net leverage is similar to Comcast at
around 4x. We estimate Disney similarly deleverages down to 2-2.5x by FY2022E, although that also assumes no buybacks post-close until FY2022. Thanks to a lower cost of debt than cost of equity, this largely debt financed hypothetical transaction is actually more accretive (mid-teens, pre PPA) to DIS EPS than its current agreed upon transaction with FOX, despite the higher purchase price

nichoman yep FCA should clamp down on it - its not reasonable to charge 1% for buying European shares
sprout If your SIPP provider is nickel-and-diming you like that, I'd consider switching....
Excel Developer but this is Hargreaves Lansdowne, @sprout
nichoman Or at least, don't let them promote international investing without prominent disclosure of FX fees
BE12:05pm

Paying 15x EBITDA-plus for Fox and gearing yourself up to 4x doesn't seem all that great an idea to me, given all media gets carried around in a very leaky bucket, but whatever I guess.
